numbered_ace_sentences: 1. There is a stand-out jump in the admission rate for legacy applicants in the 99.9% income percentile.
2. The admission rate for non-legacy applicants in the <50% income percentile is higher than the admission rate for non-legacy applicants in the 50-95% income percentile.
3. For legacy applicants, the admission rates for these income brackets do not follow this trend.
4. For legacy applicants, the admission rate increases as the income percentile increases.
5. For legacy applicants, the admission rate increases until the income percentile reaches an extreme.
6. I wonder what the admissions graph would look like if the graph used fixed yearly salaries.
7. The current graph uses income percentiles.
8. The bottom of the page states that the 99% income percentile represents an income of 620k+.
9. The bottom of the page also states that the 99.9% income percentile represents an income of 620k+.
10. I want to see how admission rates change for incomes in the millions.
11. I want to see how admission rates change for incomes in the tens of millions.
12. I want to see how admission rates change for incomes in the hundreds of millions.
13. I believe that the graph relates to Texas.
14. Many students in Texas do not apply to out-of-state colleges.
15. This is true regardless of the socioeconomic status of these students.
16. Many students in Texas apply to regional legacy schools.
17. Many students in Texas are happy with applying to regional legacy schools.
18. I am from an immigrant family in Australia.
19. I have no prior experience of the American college system.
20. Many people confine themselves to state boundaries in the American college system.
21. In Australia, state boundaries and province boundaries are not considered as much.
22. The title is: Elite Admissions Opportunities Impacted by Socio-Economic Status.
